title: Zimbabwe Starts New HIV Prevention Medicine
summary: Zimbabwe is one of the first countries to use a new medicine called lenacapavir to help prevent HIV, a serious disease. People in Zimbabwe, including young women, mothers, and some men, lined up to get an injection of this medicine. It only needs to be given twice a year, which is much easier than taking pills every day. A woman named Constance Mukoloka, who is a sex worker, got the injection and feels safer now. The medicine is free for high-risk people like sex workers, young women, and gay men. It is supported by donors from other countries. Health officials hope this new medicine will slow down new HIV infections in Zimbabwe, where many people have died from HIV over the years. The medicine is made by a company in California and is being rolled out in 10 African countries with help from programs like PEPFAR.

background_read: HIV is a virus that can make people very sick if not treated. In Zimbabwe, many people have died from HIV over the past 20 years. Prevention methods like taking pills every day can be hard for some people. The new medicine, lenacapavir, is an injection given twice a year, making it easier to use. It is being introduced in Zimbabwe and other African countries with help from donors to protect high-risk groups and reduce new infections.

WHERE: Zimbabwe, specifically in Harare, and other African countries.
WHY: To slow down new HIV infections and make prevention easier for high-risk people who struggle with daily pills.

perspectives.description: They see the new medicine as a turning point that could reshape HIV prevention strategies.
